text: hi I'm the hurricane welcome to a new
grammar lesson today we are going to
talk about intensifiers and mitigators
that how we use intensifiers and
mitigators so first let's learn what our
intensifiers now I'll tell you two
sentences one is that you look beautiful
tonight and the other one is you look
extremely beautiful tonight well which
one would you like to hear I'm sure it's
the second one you look extremely
beautiful tonight so basically what I'm
doing is I am increasing the intensity
of an adjective so I'm emphasizing on
the adjective beautiful so that's what
an intensifier is intensifiers are the
words that emphasize on another
adjective okay let's have a look at some
sentences here it's a very interesting
story so here your adjective is of
course interesting and I'm sure the
story is interesting but if you've
really liked the story and you want to
convey the same thing then you would say
that it's a very interesting story so
here the word very is your intensifier
okay so that explains that you have
really really liked the story or enjoyed
this story and that's why you have
increased the intensity of the adjective
interesting okay another sentence here
for you is everyone was extremely
excited
so here excited is your adjective and
extremely is your intensifier maybe your
tremely excited to go for a play or
maybe for a party and you are so excited
you're just so thrilled and happy that
you want to show it or tell it to
someone so you say that I was or
everyone was extremely excited okay so
extremely is the intensifier you are
emphasizing on the adjective excited now
we also use the word enough as an
intensifier okay but there's an
exception to it usually like you see
here the intensifiers are used before
the adjectives but the word enough which
is an intensifier is always used after
the adjective so if you see here I am
old enough to drive so basically I am
old enough to drive that means I do have
a license and I am old enough to drive
so old here is your adjective
whereas enough is your intensifier okay
and the last example here is he is an
exceptionally brilliant child so this
means that he is a brilliant child maybe
he's an extremely intelligent child but
you really want to put it through that
he is an exceptionally brilliant child
like there's no one like him
so here brilliant is your adjective
whereas exceptionally is your
intensifier okay now there are lots of
lots of intensifiers that you can use
for emphasizing your adjectives of
course the very common ones are very but
you can also use incredibly then we have
amazingly
and we also have enormous li okay so
these are a couple of some more
intensifiers that you can use that help
you clear with what intensifiers are
they basically these are the words that
boost your adjectives that really
intensify your adjectives and now let's
have a look at what our mitigators so
now let's learn what our mitigators
mitigators are of course the opposite of
intensifiers mitigators are the words
that reduce the intensity of the
adjectives okay
it means the ACT adjectives a little
less stronger okay so we will explain
you with the help of some sentences here
we have by the end of the party we were
rather bored so what does the sense mean
well it means that maybe you went for a
party and throughout the party you kind
of had fun but at the end you are a
little bored now here you definitely
don't want to sound very negative or
very rude by talking about the party
that it was bad because it wasn't really
bad it's just that by the end of the
party you got a little bored so that's
why you are using the mitigator that is
the word rather to suppress your
adjective that is bored okay so this
doesn't mean that you are you were
really bored if you would have said by
the end of the party we were really
bored then the word really would have
been your intensifier which would have
explained that oh my god the party was
awful and you were really bored but you
are using a mitigator
to show that the party was good but we
were a little bored so we were rather
bored it is kind of reducing the
intensity intensity of the strong
adjectives that is Borg okay let's have
a look at another
sentence the phone was quite exciting
now here exciting is your adjective and
quiet is your mitigator now let me
explain you the film was quite exciting
maybe you were really excited about this
movie okay and probably it's a sequel of
another movie and the first movie which
was released maybe a year ago and that
movie was just excellent was really
exciting and now you went for the second
one which was not as great as the first
one or maybe it was nice but it was not
like a hundred percent exciting okay so
to reduce the intensity of the word
exciting maybe to reduce it from hundred
percent to eighty percent because you
really did not enjoy some parts of the
movie so to reduce that you are using a
mitigator that is quite okay so you are
saying the film was quite exciting right
which explains that it wasn't 100%
exciting but it was not bad either
okay then another sentence here is the
food was pretty good so maybe you went
to somebody's house for dinner and
someone else to you so how's the food
how's the food and you would say the
food was pretty good now
maybe the food was not very bad okay it
it definitely had some good taste to it
but it wasn't delicious either like it
wasn't 100% either okay so to reduce the
intensity of the adjectives good you are
using the mitigator pretty okay so you
are saying the food was pretty good
which explains that it wasn't very
delicious but it was pretty good like
not bad at all okay so that exclusive
would be your medicator and then elastic
sample for you is she is a bit younger
than I am now remember we do use
mitigators with comparative adjectives
and what are comparative adjectives just
if you see here younger now young
younger and youngest would be
comparative adjectives or big bigger
biggest would be comparative adjectives
so what I mean is that we do use
mitigators with comparative adjectives
as well so this intense here she is a
bit younger than I am let's just assume
there's no a bit here okay she is
younger than I am now
that would sound or make me feel really
old isn't it so I am putting this as a
mitigator which would explain that she
is a bit younger than I am so maybe
there's not much of age difference just
maybe couple of years a couple of months
that I am older to her okay so that I
don't sound really old I am using a bit
as a mitigator with the adjective
younger okay well so these are
intensifiers and mitigators hope this is
clear to you and I will see you soon in
your next lesson and please do take a
test on this lesson too
okay you take care and have a great day
